comments.body: @yxieca Can you please review/approve.
what is '-x' can you explain how you did it?

> what is '-x' can you explain how you did it?

@lguohan 

Fix is to use -x option of pgrep to exact match on syncd. From man pgrep
-x, --exact
Only match processes whose names (or command line if -f is specified) exactly match the pattern.

@noaOrMlnx can you please update the commit header and have it related to sip dip test?
what is portchannel splits?

> what is portchannel splits?

@lguohan 
There can be few interfaces on the same portchannel. 
For example: 
 `PortChannel0002  LACP(A)(Up)  Ethernet0(S) Ethernet4(S)`

Before the change, the packet was expected to arrive only to the first interface (here, Ethernet0), even though it can arrive on any of them.
Now, it's expected to arrive on any of the interfaces.
@noaOrMlnx please clarify that in the commit description. the concept of portchannel split is not work. suggest you use portchannel with multiple ports.

Comes as a part of 
https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/pull/1675
@mykolaf we're going to try to get #1675 merged so there's no merge conflicts to deal with.

This pull request **introduces 1 alert** when merging 26934f02c57564faade73466f4436d8a10015572 into f11d076cadc638a64270f31e8b68b17ba403c6b4 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-fbd5bd76dd80e9461fafbfccf69e4818a56fd3ac)

**new alerts:**

* 1 for Variable defined multiple times

I do not remember if this test was developed in the service acl stage where we can have different implementation of the control plane acl. Now, since we have been using iptables to manage the control plane acl, and you have added many different rules. I would suggest to develop a new test which is comparing the iptables actual and expected output.

people trust iptables implementation nowadays. as long as you have correct iptable rules, we believe it will behave correctly.

> I do not remember if this test was developed in the service acl stage where we can have different implementation of the control plane acl.

Yes, you are correct, it was.

> Now, since we have been using iptables to manage the control plane acl, and you have added many different rules. I would suggest to develop a new test which is comparing the iptables actual and expected output.
> 
> people trust iptables implementation nowadays. as long as you have correct iptable rules, we believe it will behave correctly.

OK. So we should merge this PR as-is to retain the same functionality, then I can later update the test to simply verify the iptables rules are as expected.

I suspect there is something else going on as pytest recommends having conftest in a package scope (adding `__init__.py`).
https://docs.pytest.org/en/2.7.3/plugins.html?highlight=conftest

Edit: Adding `arp/__init__.py` and also adding this line to pytest.ini fixed it for me:
`norecursedirs = ptftests acstests`
Do you want to PR against master, and cherry-pick to 201811?
agree with @qiluo-msft

@qiluo-msft and @lguohan Since master branch supports the latest version of ansible from beginning and it only import the callback_loader from the new ansible path, I thought it will be ok to keep the change in master as is but for 201811, the ansible version changed later so I added this change to support both old and new ansible plugin version. 
To make the code consistent for master and 201811, I can create a new PR against master and cherry-pick to 201811.
@qiluo-msft and @lguohan ansible_host.py is removed on master with (#1658) so it's not possible to pr to master.

@daall I think we should still keep Ingress Miroring test case for ARP/ND. wr_arp testcase i don't think does everflow type mirroring. I could not confirm that from the script

> @daall I think we should still keep Ingress Miroring test case for ARP/ND. wr_arp testcase i don't think does everflow type mirroring. I could not confirm that from the script

Take a look at this script: https://github.com/Azure/sonic-utilities/blob/master/scripts/neighbor_advertiser

This is what gets setup prior to warm reboot to mirror the ARP/ND packets while the device is rebooting. It's not as explicit as this test case, but it is the same scenario.
Pushed a new commit to resolve the conflicts.

This pull request **introduces 4 alerts** and **fixes 7** when merging 20e74cbe31dac0ab12ab56a269a843caae9df03a into c31a5fb1690fd8e6ccd064114cdb5ba6856cf033 - [view on LGTM.com](https://lgtm.com/projects/g/Azure/sonic-mgmt/rev/pr-eb1d05fb3f92c01f00a26ef5a72939ea53ef3590)

**new alerts:**

* 4 for Unused import

**fixed alerts:**

* 7 for Unused import

> However, specific scenarios like config_db.json got contaminated is not addressed by this change.

What do you mean by this? Just that we can't detect config_db.json being contaminated?

> > However, specific scenarios like config_db.json got contaminated is not addressed by this change.
> 
> What do you mean by this? Just that we can't detect config_db.json being contaminated?

There is no good way of doing so. The only signal I see is having /etc/sonic/config_db.json.bak but I cannot be sure that config_db.json.bak is good. Maybe instead of using config reload, we should always go back to load minigraph. But then how do we know that minigraph is good? I feel that these are bigger problems that we need to think through before acting. Also some community members doesn't have minigraph to begin with. config reload is the common ground for all.
@yvolynets-mlnx please help review as well.

This looks good.
Did you consider the option to update "base_verification" function in section
```
    elif discard_group == "L3":
        if COMBINED_L2L3_DROP_COUNTER:
            verify_drop_counters(duthost, dut_iface, GET_L2_COUNTERS, l2_col_key)
```
instead of adding new function and call it in test case? And whats you thoughts about it?

> This looks good.
> Did you consider the option to update "base_verification" function in section
> 
> ```
>     elif discard_group == "L3":
>         if COMBINED_L2L3_DROP_COUNTER:
>             verify_drop_counters(duthost, dut_iface, GET_L2_COUNTERS, l2_col_key)
> ```
> 
> instead of adding new function and call it in test case? And whats you thoughts about it?

I think that's a good idea, it'll probably be a lot easier to maintain if we add more test cases. I guess we can pass in `ports_info` to `do_test` and `base_verification` instead of `dut_iface` and do the calculation internally, does that sound OK to you?

> 
> 
> > This looks good.
> > Did you consider the option to update "base_verification" function in section
> > ```
> >     elif discard_group == "L3":
> >         if COMBINED_L2L3_DROP_COUNTER:
> >             verify_drop_counters(duthost, dut_iface, GET_L2_COUNTERS, l2_col_key)
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> > instead of adding new function and call it in test case? And whats you thoughts about it?
> 
> I think that's a good idea, it'll probably be a lot easier to maintain if we add more test cases. I guess we can pass in `ports_info` to `do_test` and `base_verification` instead of `dut_iface` and do the calculation internally, does that sound OK to you?

Yes

My other suggestion would to make a `tests/docs` folder to put this + future documentation into (like the comment style guide).
Do you also need to change testbed.csv?

> Do you also need to change testbed.csv?

The current change does not require change being made to testbed.csv. the '[' ']' are stripped out and contents is converted to python list. The comma separate DUTs could be also used in Ansible yml file to limit execution to those specific DUTs (might not be important since we are moving away from Ansible)

However there were some touch up that I would like to make but would results in more changes such as:

1. changing 'dut' in the header line field to duts and this would require similar change to testbed.csv. 
2. Using semi colon as separator for fields while using comma as separator for duts (it is more cosmetic)
